title: **Tallow Balm That Smells Like Pear: Yeah, I Put Beef Fat On My Face
body:
Okay so I’m just gonna say it. I put beef fat on my face. Like, on purpose. The Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear, specifically. I know how it sounds. My friend Sarah looked at me like I’d grown a second head when I told her. “You’re rubbing… what? From a cow? On your… face?” Yeah. That. And you know what? My skin hasn’t been this chill in years. I’m sitting here, it’s freezing out, the heater’s making everything dry, and my face isn’t tight or itchy or anything. It’s just… fine. Weird, right? I got this little jar from an Etsy shop on a total whim because my usual stuff wasn’t cutting it and I was desperate. This whole beef tallow skincare thing kept popping up. I kept seeing “is tallow good for skin” and I was like, okay universe, I’ll bite. Or, you know, smear.

Anyway. Here’s the whole story.

## **How I Even Got Here (Spoiler: Dry Skin)**

So winter hit. Like, really hit. My skin went on strike. It was flaky, it was red, it felt like paper. I had this expensive cream from the mall, the one in the fancy jar that costs as much as my electric bill. Did nothing. Felt like I was putting plastic wrap on my face. My elbows looked like a topographical map of the moon. It was bad. I was scrolling one night, probably around midnight, just annoyed. The cat was sitting next to me judging my life choices, as usual. I stumbled on this Etsy shop talking about whipped tallow balm. Beef tallow. For your skin.

My first thought? Absolutely not. That’s for candles. Or cooking. Not my face.

But then I read a bit. And I was bored. And my credit card was right there. So I got the pear one because it sounded the least… beefy. Figured if I was gonna do this bizarre thing, it should at least smell nice.

## **Why Beef Tallow for Skin Isn't Actually Crazy**

So when the jar came, I just stared at it for a day. It’s cute, little glass jar. I opened it. Smelled like… pear? Or not. Something. Sweet but not candy sweet. Fresh. I poked it. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. Kind of waxy at first? But then it melts if you rub it between your fingers. Feels thick but then it’s gone.

Here’s the thing I had to get past: the whole “beef fat” mental block. It sounds medieval. But then I actually looked into it, which I never do, I usually just buy stuff. Turns out, tallow from grass-fed cows is kinda similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum? That’s the fancy word for it. So the idea is it doesn’t just sit on top like a lot of lotions. It actually gets in there and tells your skin it can relax, we got this. It’s like giving your skin something it already knows how to use. For stuff like eczema or just super sensitive, angry skin, that makes a lot of sense. Your skin’s not fighting a foreign substance.

It’s not like slathering raw steak on your cheeks. This stuff from this shop is whipped, it’s made in France, it’s purified. It’s a whole process. Once I wrapped my head around that, the ick factor went way down. It’s just an ingredient. Like lanolin from sheep. Or snail mucin. People put snail slime on their face! Compared to that, grass-fed cow fat seems almost normal.

## **What This Pear-Smelling Stuff Actually Does**

So I tried it. On my hands first, because I’m not an idiot. Felt… fine. Sinky. Not greasy. Didn’t make me want to wash my hands immediately. Big test. So I did my face before bed. Used a tiny bit. It felt rich. Not heavy, but like a big drink of water for my skin. Woke up and my face wasn’t an oil slick, which is what I was afraid of. It was just soft. Not “baby soft” or whatever, just… normal. Not tight. I kept doing it.

After a week, the dry patches on my cheeks were just gone. My knuckles, which always crack and bleed in winter, were healed. I started using it on my elbows. Game changer. I’m not saying it’s magic, but it fixed the problems I actually had. The tallow balm benefits for me were simple: it stopped the winter skin freak-out. It’s deeply hydrating because it mimics our own stuff, so it gets absorbed instead of sitting there. My skin just… calmed down. I didn’t have to think about it anymore.

The pear scent is subtle. It’s not a strong perfume. It’s just a light, fresh, kinda fruity thing that disappears fast. It’s nice. Makes the whole experience feel less clinical. I keep it on my nightstand. The jar’s about half gone now.

## **My Skin Now vs. Before**

Look, I’m not a skincare guru. I don’t have a ten-step routine. I wash my face and I put this on. Sometimes in the morning if it’s really cold. That’s it. The difference is I don’t have that constant background anxiety about my skin feeling tight or itchy. I don’t wake up and feel like I need to slather on three layers before I can even smile. My foundation, on the rare days I wear it, doesn’t cling to dry flakes anymore. It just sits better.

I told my mom about it. She has psoriasis sometimes on her hands. She was even more skeptical than me. “Beef fat, really?” But she tried some of mine. Called me two days later asking for the link. Said her hands felt better than they had in months. That’s the real test, right? When your mom steals your weird skincare.

I’m probably gonna order another jar soon. Maybe try the unscented one. The whole thing just works. I don’t know the science beyond the basic “it’s similar to our skin” thing, and honestly, I don’t need to. The proof is that my skin isn’t mad at me anymore. In the middle of winter, that’s a big deal.

## **Quick Questions I Get Asked**

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
For me, yeah, absolutely. The idea freaked me out at first, but it makes sense. It’s similar to the oils our skin already produces, so it absorbs really well and helps repair the skin barrier. It’s been great for my dry, winter-sensitive skin.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about this too, but nope. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t clog pores. It absorbs instead of sitting on top of the skin. My skin actually feels balanced, not greasy. If you’re super acne-prone, maybe patch test, but for my combo skin, it’s been perfect.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s light. It’s a gentle, fresh pear smell—not like a Jolly Rancher, more like a real fruit. It’s not strong at all and fades quickly after you put it on. Just a nice, subtle sweetness while you’re applying it.

So yeah. If your skin is being difficult, especially in this weather, this might be worth a shot. Getting past the initial “wait, what?” is the hardest part. After that, it’s just a really good balm that works. I got mine from a little Etsy shop, just searched for whipped tallow balm. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
random_tangent: I should probably order another jar soon
